data.text: As a side thing, French Architect designed the high-rise in the background.
Mayhem on the 80 right now. https://t.co/KZSMNvPxKh
There are true 1A idealists, but it's a tiny number, and not at all why we have a heated free-speech discourse.

Consider how the ACLU and other 1A orgs, along with journalists themselves, flipped their views on unalloyed free speech as soon as it was no longer a weapon against the right, but against the left instead. Suddenly you had pro-censorship journalists and academics.

The blackpill on liberalism and abstract rights like free speech is they're rarely promoted out of high-minded ideals, but as yet another political and narrative tool in status contests and power struggles among elites.

@spakhm What's more, Google now agrees we should be in that world. 

The same Google that once pushed back on changing results for China.

@eric_seufert You will. 

Not clear how attribution works though.
@eric_seufert Have you seen the floating barges with enormous banner ads that motor past the beaches yet?
@eric_seufert America's finest city.
@mattbilinsky We need ever more content moderation to battle ever more disinformation. It's a forever war for truth, Matt.

Every industry, especially niche but important ones like datacenter design or pharma patent law, has some leading guru figure who gets paid a fortune, everyone wants to work with, and who leads a charmed life of $2000/hour meetings between stays at their house in Puglia.

Recall the startup truism: what seem like technical problems are often human problems, which are harder to solve.

There is no 'fix' here, no censorship or algorithmic tweak that will return us to a Golden Age of Truth. We have to adapt to our creations, as we always have.
I'm happy to have returned to the world of tech where you're paid to get things right, rather than media, where you're paid to be reliably and entertainingly wrong. https://t.co/IuBrUqPruT

The content moderation grifters will soon move on to AI as the next cow they're going to milk for cushy bullshit jobs and serious-sounding studies around how people like them need to have a seat at a table they're otherwise not part of and not particularly welcome at.

Is the public forum saner now? Is there more capital 'T' Truth online? Are we less politically divided? Is everyone safer from the supposed dangers presented by social media?

'Real content moderation has never been tried!' replies the disinformation expert. And on it goes.

Is it a wonder that those who most pushed for this content moderation regime were precisely those academics and journalists who'd never spent a day working inside such platforms, or that a cottage industry of grift would sprout like mushrooms around the resulting power center?

Putting the de facto Supreme Court of free speech inside a closed-door conference room would inevitably devolve into a corporate 'Star Chamber' beyond any judicial or democratic oversight. It was a dumb idea then, and even dumber now given the timeline.

https://t.co/LoP2AWoCyf

Which is *exactly* what happened. The Twitter files show a management overwhelmed by adjudicating every issue under the sun, and indecisive both in applying and crafting policy in an ever-changing mediascape with no set rules, while also being swayed by political biases.

urls.title: Want Facebook to Censor Speech? Be Careful What You Wish For
urls.description: Facebook is caught between the legal definition of "hate speech" and the more expansive common understanding of the term.

data.text:

https://t.co/lzd5yVkhQW

urls.title: Inside Meta’s Oversight Board: 2 Years of Pushing Limits
urls.description: Mark Zuckerberg set up the panel to investigate how his company handles controversial posts. Now its members want to transform how social platforms work.

urls.title: Twitter Isn't Shadow-Banning Republicans. Here's Why.
urls.description: President Trump tweeted about the platform "SHADOW BANNING" conservatives. Twitter clarified that a bug was making it impossible to search for specific accounts and the company says it is fixing it.

One day, one day…

I still find it kind of astonishing how ready American foodies are to do it.

Under capitalism, they wait in line for their trendy food trucks. https://t.co/NU9pk6T2Gv

Long lunch with a prominent tech journalist trying to reconcile the 'two cultures' (as someone who's seen a bit of both sides). 

I think the gap is now unbridgeable. But I also think that's true around just every culture-war divide right now.

So the Time Person of the Year actually was someone legitimately prominent whose achievements both drove and characterized the as-yet unwritten history of our year. 

Imagine that.
For those not familiar, in New York you can be able to afford a place, but if the board doesn't approve the deal doesn't happen. Just. Like. That.

I love how when buying an apartment in New York there's this co-op board bullshit where they apply every manner of elitist social filtering, but in Miami, the filter is just out-hustling and out-smarting everyone else in the poker hand of a Miami real estate deal.
@mr_james_c https://t.co/jgny5g7pNP
@Ingleby18 Late 90s. I did lots of random backpacking.

Our children will likely never know that feeling of simply wandering unconnected through the world, lost in the happenstance of the moment, where anything (or nothing) could happen. They won’t even be able to imagine it.

Random memory of riding a train from Tangier to Marrakesh, and how you used to go to farflung places with no real way to communicate to anyone you knew or even easily know what’s going on globally. If you jumped off the train into the desert, you were lost to oblivion.
@nawBitbot Lol. Even fewer among the young even know what a movie is.

Not only have I not seen any of these, I haven’t even *heard* of a single one.

Things are moving fast enough now that someone not very old can watch as entire genres that once occupied the brightest minds—film, novels, theater—lapse entirely into cultural irrelevance. https://t.co/f1LDhoQWrL
Mister Argos would like a word. https://t.co/Kx5VzefPoo

I was trying to find anything made now like that dining table, that could be almost any length, and then folded into nothing. 

I didn't quite realize what a historic piece my parents had somehow managed to acquire while living in California.

This used to be the dining table in our childhood home. It was gorgeous wood and joinery, coupled to ingenious design that folded a banquet table into something just one foot wide when stored.

My barbarian father let it go in a rummage sale. 

https://t.co/S9fNpAE4f3

data.text:
@mg One of my great beer memories is having Pliny for the first time (would have been around 2009) at Monk's Kettle. The aroma was overpowering, and the taste life-changing. I became a beer snob after that.

And somehow it just doesn't evoke that now.
@thomasschiavone I bought the last 4-pack mind you, but the one in Inner Mission.

Unlike many famous and historic beers (ahem, Pliny) whose once pathbreaking taste is now surpassed by far more inventive and sophisticated styles, Heady Topper is still pretty damn good. 

Perfect balance of malt and hops, and within the hop profile, fruit and pine. https://t.co/TXu7azX9HI

Kind of can’t believe I ran across one of the most celebrated and elusive beers in America randomly at my local Gus’s.

Had to buy it. https://t.co/9iSPyVoumc

The closest parallel is life in dictatorships like Cuba, where everyone understands much of life is a lie, but you have to keep different narrative registers of varying veracity with different people as a way of life. It becomes second nature to people, as it has here.

There’s obviously so much politically-motivated deflection and padding to so many ChatBot answers around The Culture War Things. It’s funny how we accept the misleading HR-speak as just the way things are now. So obviously bullshit, and yet essential pieties we must all intone.

I like how Miami corrects two of the most obnoxious aspects of American dining culture:
1. None of this “you can’t be seated until your whole party is here” bullshit
2. Flat service fee by default, death to tipping culture

The Miami version of those heart statues in SF are these painted roosters in Little Havana. 

This one is dressed like a mambí, the Cuban rebels against Spanish rule in the 19th century. La Carreta is kind of like the Cuban Denny’s (but much better food). https://t.co/0qqsqiLFNf
Jarring to see hard adult looks from children. https://t.co/yanxZ7NgZ9

But since FTX was the union of worsts--the obscurity of centralized finance but the lack of regulation and oversight of crypto--SBF was able to get away with a massive fraud that couldn't have happened in traditional finance, or in fully decentralized finance.

The tl;dr for non-crypto normies: if FTX had actually been a fully crypto-style decentralized exchange, this implosion would have been caught far earlier, as somebody snooping around Dune (a blockchain query engine) would have easily spotted the shenanigans and raised a stink.

The real question (and indictment of crypto) is why the centralized versions of everything manage to get most of the consumer adoption, while the full-blown versions struggle to gain broader adoption.

It's interesting FTX is being held up as emblematic of the ecosystem, when technologically it's just a normie Web 2 online casino that happened to trade crypto-assets.

Seems a subtle distinction, but it's not as the fully decentralized version of the above stayed unaffected.

If only we'd invented some way of easily creating financial accounts--let's call them 'wallets'--as well as a publicly-visible ledger of transfers, so that both oversight and accounting would be easy and transparent.

https://t.co/swk0AZk2d9 https://t.co/CllfskwMft

urls.title: WSJ News Exclusive | FTX Founder Sam Bankman-Fried Says He Can’t Account for Billions Sent to Alameda
urls.description: FTX’s founder said he couldn’t explain what happened to billions of dollars that customers of his failed cryptocurrency exchange sent to the bank accounts of his trading firm.

In squash, a small college in New England hit on the idea of offering a free ride to good international squash players.

The Colombians and Indians proceeded to crush the future McKinsey consultants from Harvard and Yale. 

https://t.co/wshAOBOty3

urls.title: Squashing the Ivies (Published 2011)
urls.description: A nice little school gets mentioned in the same breath as Harvard, Princeton and Yale by whipping them on the squash court, over and over again.

data.text:
@octal The paid NZ crews do wonderfully in a race put together by Americans and not raced by anyone else.

US is non-existent in ocean sailing more generally.

The story there is that sailing and squash are aristocratic yankee sports done by the upper class as a hobby in their finishing schools. In sailing powerhouses like New Zealand and Oz it’s more of a working class sport open to all (everyone potters about in boats on islands).

It is kind of disappointing and pathetic the US does so poorly internationally in sports it could absolutely dominate if it tried. 

I’m of course talking about the only two sports that matter: sailing and squash.
